parkName: Bainbridge Island Japanese American Exclusion Memorial National Historic Site
description: A memorial to the unconstitutional, forced removal and incarceration of 272 Japanese Americans from Bainbridge Island on March 30, 1942 as a result of Executive Order 9066. The memorial was built on the exact path to the Eagledale dock where residents were forced to depart to be sent to concentration camps. üïäÔ∏è ''A large Western Red Cedar that stood near the Eagledale ferry dock as Bainbridge Islanders were forced to leave their homes in 1942 ‚Äî and that still stands on the site of the Memorial ‚Äî was added to the National Registry of Historic Trees in 2003 by the American Forests organization. Only the second West Coast tree to earn this distinction, it is considered a living witness to an event that helped shape our nation.'' (quoted from BIJAEMA website) üïäÔ∏è The NPS description of this historic site can be found at: https://www.nps.gov/miin/learn/historyculture/bainbridge-island-japanese-american-exclusion-memorial.htm üïäÔ∏è Although a small government trailer exists on grounds, mail can not be delivered to it. General information inquiries should therefore be addressed to the non-profit organization BIJAEMA instead of the national park service
visitorCenterHours: Hours: 9am ‚Äì 5pm, 7 days a week, March 1st -- December 1st

description: This park consists of the historic (1850s) Ebey family farm on Whidbey Island with trails thru meadows and woods overlooking views of the Salish Sea and Puget Sound.

Quote: ''An active volcano, Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the contiguous U.S., spawning 5 major rivers. Subalpine wildflower meadows ring the icy volcano while ancient forest cloaks Mount Rainier‚Äôs lower slopes.'' The peak of the volcano is 14,410 feet above sea level. ‚õ∞Ô∏è TIMED ENTRY RESERVATIONS MAY BE REQUIRED from May thru September, 7am-5pm. CHECK OFFICIAL NPS WEBSITE FOR THE LATEST INFO (For example, timed entry is paused for the Paradise Corridor in 2025 but STILL ACTIVE for the Sunrise Corridor in 2025). Each corridor requires a separate vehicle reservation. Timed entry reservations are good for a single day, per vehicle, and are required in addition to an entrance fee or park pass.
visitorCenterHours: June - Sept, 9am-4:30pm daily @ Longmire Museum at Longmire Wilderness Information Center üå≤üå≤ June - Sept, 9:30am-5:30pm daily @ Henry M Jackson Memorial Visitor Center üå≤üå≤ June - Sept, 9am-5pm daily @ Ohanapecosh Visitor Center üå≤üå≤ July - Sept, 9am-5pm daily @ Sunrise Visitor Center

description: Explore an alpine landscape that contains over 300 glaciers and one of the largest ranges of biodiversity of any national park in the U.S.! Most of the park is designated as wilderness, and exploring its remote, mountainous content can be dangerous for inexperienced hikers and rock climbers.  There are no entrance fees, but there also is almost no road access and permits are required year round for overnight stays in almost all of the park.
visitorCenterHours: Visitor Center Hours: 9am-5pm every day during Summer.

description: This park combines glaciated mountains, oceanside views, and a temperate rainforest!  It is designated as both a World Heritage Site and an International Biosphere Reserve by the United Nations!  Many plant and animal species are found only here and nowhere else on Earth!  Although the main park visitor center is open almost every day of the year, the Hoh Rain Forest center is only open during the summer (9am-5pm), requires driving over 30 miles away from the nearest amenities, and often becomes congested with stand-still traffic jams on weekends.
visitorCenterHours: Port Angeles Visitor Center: Open year-round. 9 am - 5 pm in Summer; 9 am - 4 pm the rest of the year.

parkName: San Juan Island National Historical Park
description: Since it is located on an island, travel to this national park is limited to only visitors who arrive by boat or air. Historically, ownership of the island was divided between the U.S. and Great Britian, and the two countries almost went to war over it in 1859. Educational historical reinactments often take place during the summer and there are over 23 miles of trails inside the park. Animal viewing highlights include the Island Marble Butterfly (previously feared extinct), whales, black colored red foxes, and several popular bird species.
visitorCenterHours: During the summer, both the American Camp Visitor Center and English Camp Visitor Center are open Thurs - Tues from 10AM - 3PM.

description: This site commemorates an important Presbyterian missionary stop on the Oregon Trail.  A deadly measles outbreak in 1847 led Native Americans to murder 13 of the white settlers, take another 47 of them hostage, and sparked the 8 year long Cayuse War with the U.S.
